meta_data.title: If You Ever Cross Harpagus, Make Sure Not to Put Him In Charge of Your Army After That
meta_data.subtitle: I'm putting a bunch of work into my website so that it's easy to search and access the entire podcast back catalog; including the series on Matthew and the series where we went through the whole Bible, covering one book per episode. My YouTube stuff...

transcription_data.text: Hey, everybody, I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast, and we are doing a deep dive into the historical background behind the book of Esther. We're trying to get a sense of this achaemenid dynasty, these kings who ruled over Persia and who were very colorful characters surrounded by very colorful characters. Now, in addition to the story that we've been working through about the origins of Persia and the origins of this dynasty, in addition to that, just being ludicrously juicy and salacious and interesting and dramatic and good, it is also in a practical sense helpful to you and I in the task of positioning ourselves to understand the book of Esther, because we're getting a sense of how storytelling worked at this time. We're getting a sense of the twists of justice and the expectations of an audience member at this moment in history when they were reading Herodotus, when they were reading Xenophon, when they were reading T.C.S., those three Greek guys who wrote about a lot of this stuff. And if we understand what their expectations were when they were reading the storytelling of those guys, it might help us to better understand what their expectations were and what the rhythms of good storytelling sounded like when that same audience would have encountered the book of Esther. So, for those of you who are less fans of the history side of this conversation, I just want to take a minute and say, you rule, I commend you, because if you don't like history, you don't like history. I don't know how you don't like history. I think it's just awesome. But hey, I understand it's not everybody's bag and we're doing a big setup for this book here. So, thank you for absorbing this whole story and trusting that it's going to pay off as we get into the actual book of the Bible that we're setting out to look at. At this point, we're only a couple of kings away from the one we run into in the book of Esther. When we left off yesterday, Cyrus's grandpa, the king of the Medes, a guy named Astra, Astayages, had just carried out a brutally ruthless cruel punishment against his right hand man, Harpeggus, for not obeying an order to kill young baby Cyrus Astayages' grandson. I'm not going to say again what that punishment was in case you were plugging your ears yesterday. Just know it's like the most horrifying, gross, awful thing that anybody could possibly dream up or imagine. And Harpeggus, who is the guy who brings that story to us, he tells us that Harpeggus took that somewhat personally and did not quickly forget it. Harpeggus writes, Harpeggus sought to become Cyrus's friend and sent him gifts because he desired to take vengeance on Astayages. And then it goes on to say, Harpeggus communicated secretly with the chief men of the Medes and persuaded them that they must make Cyrus their leader and cause Astayages to cease from being king. Now, I told you yesterday, we're going back and forth between the interesting version of the story and the boring version of the story. The boring version is the only one that we can really say with certainty. It's our best guess based on actual evidence. But then there's also the interesting version and that's the one that we get from Herodotus. Well, sometimes the interesting version provides a plausible explanation for what happens in the boring version. Long story short, Cyrus grows up as we talked about. He gets married, he has kids and Astayages ultimately sends Harpeggus to lead the invasion of Persia after Cambysus I is dead and Cyrus is now king as a grown man after 559 BC. Well, it's generally accepted by historians that the Medes probably would have won that fight if all of the Medes had continued to fight on the side of the Medes. But interestingly, Harpeggus gets onto the battlefield and switches sides with his army over to Cyrus and then Cyrus and the Persians easily defeat Astayages and the Medes. Why would Harpeggus do that? Well, maybe in reality, he did it because he could just read the writing on the wall and he was like, Cyrus is probably going to win the future is Cyrus. Astayages is kind of crazy. He believes in weird dreams. He's paranoid. I'm going to cast my lot with this young Buck Cyrus. Maybe all that crazy stuff that we read about yesterday is what actually happened and Harpeggus was harboring this grudge and much like Cyrus who was very good at doing not just the expedient thing but the expedient thing in the right moment. Maybe Harpeggus was like, I'm going to wait until it would hurt Astayages the most to play my hand and take my revenge for what he did to my son and what he did to me. Now, I'm giving you the quick version here. This took a few years to work out and eventually Cyrus conquers the capital of the Medes which is a place called Ekbatana. This will be an important town. It'll be a summer retreat up in the high country for Persian kings for decades, even centuries to come. And it's with that capture of Ekbatana that Astayages is deposed and now just out of nowhere in the matter of just a few years, the Persians have the upper hand in this whole scramble for power in the ancient world. But Cyrus is clever. He knows that he is not well enough established to just say, I own everything now. Everybody bend the knee. Instead, he has to woo the remaining Medes. He has to make all of their bannermen and allies like the idea of working with Cyrus now instead of with Astayages. And so Cyrus shows mercy to his grandpa Astayages. Doesn't kill him. In fact, Herodotus says that he treats him pretty well in his forced early retirement. And Cyrus even takes a second wife, Amethyst, the daughter of Astayages. Now, you're probably doing the math on all of this and you're like, if he married his grandpa's daughter, aren't we getting into like an I am my own grandpa kind of situation here? And the answer is yes. That's getting weird. See, he married his aunt. And then after that, there's going to be some sibling intermarriage that happens within this accumulated dynasty. And it gets real weird and real backwards. And I haven't gamed it all the way out to figure out who becomes related to themselves, how as a result of all of this. But this was done back then. Marriages pacified hard feelings and marriages ensured alliances. It was almost like really classy high-end hostage exchanges to ensure good behavior. Now, here's the truth. Even though people tried to heap really flattering titles on Astayages, history does not remember him as Astayages the Great. And they do remember Cyrus as Cyrus the Great. Cyrus was an instant upgrade at the head coach position for all of the Medes and the Persians. And because of his sheer competence alone and his level-headed leadership, they became the instant favorite to win the competition for who would be the next great empire, even though Babylon theoretically held that title. They held it very loosely. And it's only a matter of a few years before the Medes and the Persians, but really the Persians in 539 conquer the city of Babylon. Now, this is recorded in the book of Daniel. You might remember this business where we at time-wise. Tomorrow, we're going to read from the book of Daniel about the moment where Babylon fell apart and Persia came to town. And we're going to see how those events in Daniel move us a lot closer to what's going on in Esther. All right, Daniel tomorrow, I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon. Thank you to all of you who have taken the time to leave a rating and review on your podcast apps. We're grateful because it's encouraging and it helps new people find their way here.
